title: How tactical voting could have a massive impact on election winners and losers
text:
This year’s General Election and the course of Brexit could be decided by tactical voting (Picture: AFP/REUTERS)

Boris Johnson is on course to win a Commons majority unless Remain voters work tactically to block a Tory victory, research has revealed.

The Conservatives are tipped to achieve a majority of 44 seats if no tactical voting took place.

However, Remainers could scupper this, according to a study by the Best for Britain campaign.

They said if less than a third of Remain voters (30%) used their vote tactically, they could swing the election.

It would secure a Remain majority of four and potentially block Brexit.

Boris Johnson is preparing for a tough fight to get a majority in December’s general election (Picture: Getty)

The research by the anti-Brexit campaign was based on seat-by-seat analysis of 46,000 people over September and October.

It was released on Wednesday, hours after the Commons voted to back a December 12 poll.

Advertisement

If 40% of pro-Remain voters worked tactically then they could return a majority of 36, reflecting their Brexit views, according to the research.

The study was carried out by the Focaldata polling agency using a technique known as multi-level regression and post-stratification, a method that reportedly gave a rare but accurate prediction that Donald Trump would become US president in 2016.

Where do the parties broadly stand on Brexit? The Conservatives want to take Britain out of the EU. The Labour Party want to renegotiate with the EU and put a new deal to the public, in which voters could remain. The Lib Dems would vote to revoke Article 50 and cancel Brexit. The Brexit Party want to leave the EU without a deal.

The 2019 General Election – the third in four years – is likely to be one of the most unpredictable in history.

Both Leave and Remain are rushing to create tactical voting apps to maximise their support.

The tactical.vote website has promised to provide voters with details of how to ‘stop the Tories’ by entering their postcode.

Their website said: ‘The UK uses an election system called first-past-the-post, where the candidate who gets the most votes in each constituency wins.

‘This makes it possible for candidates – and a government – to get elected without winning the support of anywhere near a majority of the voters, if the opposition is split across multiple parties.

‘To overcome this problem, you can look at the results of the previous election in your constituency, and then vote for a party that might not be your first choice, but is the one that has the best chance of beating the Conservatives where you live.’

British Labour Party leader Jeremy Corbyn finally gave his backing to a December election (Picture: EPA)

Corbyn support group Momentum is targeting students with the Univotes website, where they can enter their home and university postcodes to find out where their votes will make the biggest impact for Labour.

Advertisement

Advertisement

Nigel Farage’s Brexit Party had said it wants to target all 600 seats in the election.

But one of their most senior MEPs, John Lonsworthy, said it should focus on 20 mostly pro-Leave Labour seats in order not to scupper Mr Johnson’s delivery of Brexit.

The MEP for Yorkshire and the Humber added: ‘I think it is important for us to be sensible.

‘I think we ought to be targeted in terms of the number of seats that we decide to address.

‘I can imagine that might be 20 or 30. They would be entirely winnable then if you poured all your resources into them.

‘You would probably not get any more if you concentrated on the 600. But you would also get a better result for Brexit too.’

Nigel Farage’s Brexit Party has been advised to try in fewer constituencies in order to get its first MP (Picture: Reuters)

The Tories have been warned they need to win 50 Labour seats to offset expected losses to Remainers in Scotland and the South.

They are set to target the so-called ‘Workington Man’ – who is older, white, non-graduate and male living in rugby league towns in the North of England.

Onward, a right-leaning think-tank, said these people voted Leave in the EU referendum but are typically Labour voters.

The constituency of Workington, Cumbria, will be the bellweather seat and is currently held by Labour’s Sue Hayman with a 4,000 majority.

Will Tanner, director of Onward, said: ‘This election will be the most volatile in living memory and no party should be complacent.

Advertisement

‘But it is clear that the Conservatives’ path to victory runs through working-class rugby league towns like Workington, Warrington and Wigan, which usually do not give them a second thought – as well as the party’s leafy heartlands in the South of England.’

Jo Swinson will be campaigning to stop Brexit (Picture: PA)

The Lib Dems, who currently have 19 seats, have been ‘revived’ in the polls at around 18%.

They will be pushing a clear Remain policy and Chukka Umunna said he believes they can double their current tally of MPs.

Polling expert Sir John Curtice has warned that the UK could be on track for another hung Parliament.

Those with the most votes could try to strike up a coalition with one or more smaller parties.

The Tories, DUP and the Brexit Party would be the most likely to come together to finish off Brexit.

Labour could try and sign a pact with the Lib Dems or the SNP or both.
